title: Modelling the Compatibility of Licenses
segmentation: Thank you, so yes, I'm a PhD students from the University of Nantes and open that as of company.
And then in this presentation I will explain all week and model eyes, compatibility relation between licenses.
So first little bit of context, so modern web facilitates encourage the combination of resources so resources can be linked.
Data can be a source code, web services.
We have a resource producers that use licenses to protect their resources.
And the licenses specify the condition of reuse of resources.
So what action are permitted?
Published, prohibited, recommended, etc.

That must be protected with a license that is compliant with the license of combining resources.
So here license three is compliant.
Must be compliant with license one and license too.
Because we combine resource one resource too.
So we say that a license L3 is compliant with the license and you.
If a resource protected by L2.
Can be protected by L3 without violating condition of reuse of L2.
We also have the compatibility relation between licenses, so it's the inverse relation of compliance.
So L1 and L2 must be compatible with L3.
And compatibility relation between licenses.
Gives information about potential re usability of resources.
So for example here because L1 and L2 are compatible with all three, we can say that air one and Air 2 can be reused with resource 3.
And in general, we say that L1 and L2 are less restrictive than L3.
And it's may exist alot of other license that could protect this combination.
So we know the world.
It may exist a lot of licenses that are also compliant with L1 and L2, and in this context choosing an appropriate license for combination of resource of or just for resource.
It can be difficult, so one risk is to choose a license that is too restrictive and that will block the re usability of the resource.
And the other risk is to take a license that is too permissive and that will not protect enough the resource in the future.
So we assume.
That a model that can order licenses will make this choice easier.
So our research problem is given.
A specific license 02 automatically positions license in assets of licenses in terms of compatibility and compliance, and we want to generalize this process to do it automatically.
While taking into account the semantic affection because it can impact compatibility.
Swing
As a related work, we already have work that address the problem of license compatibility.
We already have license based tool for examples that help user choose a license for resource, but this kind of tool only return a set of license.
But this set of license is not order headed in terms of compatibility and compliance.
So it can be hard to.
To see the impact the choice of license will have on the usability of the resource, we have other words that address the problem of license combination.
OK, so given 1 two or more licenses to find a license that is compliant with these licenses.
But this kind of of tools of of of research works proposed to find often the least restrictive license that is compliant with the set of license to combine, or if it returns a set of license.
This set of licenses not ordered in terms of compatibility and compliance.
So it's the same problem that license based tools.

We have another work in the domain of the open source software that use a compatibility graph to see if source code can be reused together, but this compatibility graph is made by hand, so if you want to add a new license that is not known.
Have to be done by hand.
And finally we have in the domain of access control we have lattice based models that proposed to order a class of security in terms of restrictiveness.
So it can order automatically class of securities, but this kind of tools were not used in the domain of licenses or usage control.
So we propose a Kelly.
So.
Ali is a lattice based model that partially order licenses in terms of compatibility.

So it uses the restrictiveness relation as a basis because it's more easy to order automatically licensed but by restrictiveness, and then it used constraints to identify which restrictiveness relation are also compatibility relation.
And we also have a prototype of a license based search engine that I presented yesterday during the demo session.

So in this example I will take a simple set of action of two actions, the ability to read the resource, and the ability to modify the resource.
So licensing is in this work is just a function that assign an action to a status.

It's just an example of license using our previous restrictiveness lattice of statues, and our set of actions.

So we obtain action lattices right here.

So for example, the first one say that.
The permission to read is less restrictive than the prohibition to it, and it's the same thing for the modification action.
And then by doing the product of these action lattices.
We obtain the set of all possible license in this context partially ordered by restrictiveness.

We can generate non valid licenses.
OK, so non valid licenses are licenses that cannot be used to protect a resource because for example it have a contradiction in it.
So if we look at a license to, for example here.
We see that modification is permitted, but the.
The Read action is prohibited.

Constraints that identify.

In the red, because they will not be.
They will not be identified as compatibility relation now.

And if we remember the definition of compliance and compatibility, this definition supposed to modify the license of a resource.
And it's this context we consider that modifying the license of a resource is the same as modifying the resource itself.
So we want to avoid.
License that poi beats modification to be compatible with other license.
And notice that license for can be compliance with License 3.
So license constraints are not enough to avoid this kind of problem.
So we use compatibility constraints that.
Function.
That takes a restrictiveness relation in parameter, so 22 licenses that have restrictiveness relation and that return true if it's a compatibility relation or false otherwise.
So by using this example of constraints.
We identify the relation between L3 and L4 as a non compatibility relation.

A resource protected by L1.
Can be reused with a resource protected by Alpha, but the resource protected by L3 cannot be reused with a resource protected by Alpha.
The Wiz this four elements Kelly can automatically order licenses in terms of compatibility and compliance.
So we see that the size of a galley ordering depends on the size of.
The restrictiveness lattice of statues, so the number of statues.
And on the number of action.

So for example, if we take a vocabulary like or derailleur with 72 actions and at least four statues with this at the size of the Cali ordering are huge, so the size of Kelly ordering are growing exponentially.
So that's why we proposed a.
So an algorithm that can generate subgraphs of Kelly ordering of size N in N per 2 / 2 comparison at most.
And this algorithm can also insert a new license in an existing so graph of size N in linear time.
So this algorithm is available on GitHub under an MIT license.
And.
We have another contribution I showed during the demo session yesterday, so it's a license based search engine.
So this license based search engine is work.
On Kelly ordering that is inspired by Odiele vocabulary.
So it contains a set of 72 action former derail restrictiveness lattice of statues, inspired by the rules of odl and the constraints inspired by Odeon.
And using.
The algorithm it can generate a subgraph of the skelly ordering and it can assign resources to licenses.
And use this compatibility graph to answer question like for example, finds the license and resources that can be reused and given license.
And it kind.
It can evaluate the impact of a license on the re usability of A of a resource.
So this search engine is also available on GitHub under an MIT license.
So to conclude.
We have Kelly Kelly on sale with such questions so it can partially order licenses in terms of compatibility and compliance.
We have an algorithm to order on these subsets of Kelly orderings.
And we have a use case about the type of license based search engines that showed the feasibility and the usability of our model.
So notice that Kelly does not intend to provide a legal advice.
OK, but it's I am that's encouraging and facilitating the reuse of license, said resources.
Anne.

In the in perspective, in future work we want to extend Kelly to take into account other aspects of license that can impact compatibility to, for example, the jurisdiction or time validity of licenses.
And we want to take into account compatibility relation that are not based on their restrictiveness relation.

So in our case some license provider can define compatibility relation between their licenses without restrictiveness relation between them so so we want to take into account this kind of compatibility relation.
And another work is to define function to to pass from a Kelly ordering to another.
So for example, if we have multiple application that use different Kelly ordering so different sets of action, different set of statues.
Oh, to define the whole nation between these licenses, is it possible to define compatibility relation between licenses from two different Kelly ordering?
So that's all for me.
If you have any question about this, I will be pleased to answer.
